title: 107_hr4793
content: The Act titled "Mosquito Abatement for Safety and Health Act" amends the Public Health Service Act to provide grants for the prevention of mosquito-borne diseases to political subdivisions and states. The Act "Mosquito Abatement for Safety and Health Act" allows the Secretary to grant funds to political subdivisions for mosquito control programs to prevent and control mosquito-borne diseases. Preference is given to areas with a high incidence of mosquito-borne diseases. The Act allows the Secretary to grant funds to political subdivisions for mosquito control programs. Subdivisions must coordinate activities with contiguous areas and demonstrate significant need for control programs. Grants are contingent on conducting assessments to determine immediate needs. The Act allows grants for mosquito control programs in political subdivisions. Subdivisions must assess immediate needs and develop a plan for the program. Matching funds are required for the costs of the program. The Act allows grants for mosquito control programs in political subdivisions. Matching funds are required for the costs of the program, which may be in cash or in kind. Federal contributions or services subsidized by the Federal Government cannot be included in determining non-Federal contributions. The Secretary may waive the matching funds requirement in cases of extraordinary economic conditions. Reports on the grant must be submitted to the Secretary. The Act allows grants for mosquito control programs in political subdivisions. Grants may not exceed $100,000 per fiscal year, and each subdivision can only receive one grant. The Secretary can make assessment grants to political subdivisions for conducting programs. The Act allows grants to political subdivisions for mosquito control programs. Grants cannot exceed $10,000 per fiscal year, and each subdivision can only receive one grant. The Secretary can also make coordination grants to States for program coordination. The Act allows grants to political subdivisions for mosquito control programs, with certain requirements for coordination and planning at the state level. The Act allows grants to political subdivisions for mosquito control programs, with requirements for coordination and monitoring at the state level. States must submit reports to the Secretary detailing their activities and program evaluations. The Act allows grants to political subdivisions for mosquito control programs, with requirements for coordination and monitoring at the state level. Grants may not exceed $10,000 per fiscal year, and a state may only receive one grant. Applications for grants must be submitted to the Secretary with necessary information as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary may provide training and technical assistance for control programs and assessments. Definitions include 'control program' and 'political subdivision' as local jurisdictions below the state level. The Secretary may recognize an area under the jurisdiction of other entities of general government as a political subdivision for purposes of this Act. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2003, with additional appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2007 for control programs in response to mosquito-borne diseases. The National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences will conduct research on controlling insect populations that transmit diseases to humans. This includes developing methods to reduce the health risks associated with these diseases.
